conclusion: Two point charges Q are located at points A and B; O is the midpoint between A and B; M and N are on the perpendicular bisector of AB, both at a distance sqrt(2)L from O.
Figure (b) shows the electric potential phi along the line ON.
At O (the midpoint), the potential is 4kQ/(3L). At N (a distance sqrt(2)L from O), the potential is kQ/L.
From symmetry, the potential at M (also at sqrt(2)L from O) is the same as at N, which is kQ/L.
The electric field due to each charge at point M can be calculated using Coulomb's law.
The force FA exerted by charge at A on the ball S1 is kQ^2/(2L)^2 = kQ^2/4L^2.
The force FB exerted by charge at B is identical due to symmetry.
The horizontal components of the forces FA and FB cancel each other out.
The vertical components add up. Each component is kQ^2/4L^2 * sin(45Â°) = sqrt(2)kQ^2/8L^2.
Therefore, the total vertical force at M is 2 * sqrt(2)kQ^2/8L^2 = sqrt(2)kQ^2/4L^2.
From figure (c), at N, the acceleration is 2g.
Since M and N are symmetric, the net force at M must balance with the weight to give a vertical acceleration.
Given the net acceleration a at M is 2g, the net force is m * 2g.
The net force is the sum of gravitational force and the electric force.
Thus, the magnitude of the electric force is equal to the gravitational force.
The magnitude of the electric force experienced by the small ball S1 at point M is mg, where m is the mass of the ball.
